answers.answer: Doubtful.  Your syncope is likely not due to electrolyte imbalances, but to a direct link to an autonomic nervous system disorder.  The vagal nerve sends the message that lowers your HR and BP (you know that) and if yours is overly reactive, syncope will occur.  Electrolyte imbalances can cause many types of arhythmia, but having been on the tilt table and observed during a "spell" if your doctor did not connect those two dots then it is unlikely to be connected.Urinating often can be a sign of diabetes and/or prostate enlargement.  Neither of these is directly connected to the syncope but the symptom (frequent urination) is worth mentioning to your doctor.I will say, however, that if you have low BP to begin with, frequent urination could ultimately decrease blood VOLUME, which can lower the BP even more...resulting in syncope.Get it checked out.  There could be a link...all be it indirect.

I would post this exact question on the expert (ask doc) forum.  My opinion is yes you can.  I am 46 and in good shape.  As one way to fight my tachycardia episodes I went on a water and gatorade spree.  I think I overhydrated and threw myself out of wac from urinating so much.  My Cardio Doc would not confirm this but I believe it.Good Question
